items.text: **Spahn Ranch** was an [[LINK|lang_en|Electro-industrial|electro-industrial]] group from [[LINK|lang_en|Los_Angeles|Los Angeles]]. Active from 1992 to 2000, the band was well known in a subgenre of industrial music for its fusion of [[LINK|lang_en|Electronic_dance_music|electronic dance]], [[LINK|lang_en|Industrial_Music|industrial]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Gothic_music|gothic]] music.

The band was formed in 1992 in Los Angelos by [[LINK|lang_en|Matt_Green_(musician)|Matt Green]] and his New Yorkâ€“based collaborator, Rob Morton. They collectively used the funds they had saved up to jump-start the band. Rob Morton had been Matt Green's musical partner for the 5 years prior. That same year in 1992, they signed to [[LINK|lang_en|Cleopatra_Records|Cleopatra Records]] and released a self-titled, four-song [[LINK|lang_en|Extended_play|EP]], with vocals supplied by Scott "Chopper" Franklin (later to become bass player for [[LINK|lang_en|The_Cramps|The Cramps]]) Scott Franklin left another band to provide vocals for Spahn Ranch.

In 1993, they added vocalist [[LINK|lang_en|Athan_Maroulis|Athan Maroulis]] and recorded their debut album, *Collateral Damage*. Their second album, *The Coiled One*, appeared two years later in the midst of Morton leaving the band due to creative and logistical differences. After his departure, the line-up was expanded to include [[LINK|lang_en|Christian_Death|Christian Death]] drummer David Glass, Screams for Tina guitarist Kent Bancroft, and Tubalcain drummer Harry Lewis. This offered a beginning of the fuller, more diverse, dark electro-industrial sound that Spahn Ranch would continue to pursue. By 1997, Spahn Ranch had pared themselves down to the three-piece unit of Green, Maroulis and Lewis.
Spahn Ranch continued to release albums throughout the late 1990s.

*Architecture*, released in 1997, featured contributions from [[LINK|lang_en|Killing_Joke|Killing Joke]] / [[LINK|lang_en|Prong_(band)|Prong]] bassist [[LINK|lang_en|Paul_Raven_(musician)|Paul Raven]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Rockats|Rockats]] / [[LINK|lang_en|Nancy_Sinatra|Nancy Sinatra]] guitarist [[LINK|lang_en|Danny_B._Harvey|Danny B. Harvey]]. This album took an even more experimental approach to the Spahn Ranch sound, incorporating elements of drum and bass, dub and for the first time, live guitar parts. *Beat Noir*, in 1998, followed a similar path even further and included work with [[LINK|lang_en|Bauhaus_(band)|Bauhaus]] / [[LINK|lang_en|Love_and_Rockets_(band)|Love & Rockets]] bassist [[LINK|lang_en|David_J|David J]].

The band regularly toured throughout North America during their existence with the likes of [[LINK|lang_en|Front_Line_Assembly|Front Line Assembly]], [[LINK|lang_en|Front_242|Front 242]], [[LINK|lang_en|Switchblade_Symphony|Switchblade Symphony]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Apoptygma_Berzerk|Apoptygma Berzerk]]. Spahn Ranch also made a couple of European treks prior to their demise as a group in 2000.
*Closure*, their final album, was recorded in 2000 and released in 2001.
